column10: b"b' New feature:  custom templates'"

b'b" This PR proposes a major new feature into which is the ability for the user to have their own custom templates applied on top of the standard structure during in order to tailor the environment to their own needs.  If the first thing you do after is to add a
column11: twiddle with the library settings in or add a knitr template with your favourite report layout
column12: then this feature will be for you.  Perhaps your organisation or department has a standard set of analysis flow
column13: reports or directory structure that you need to adhere to.  They can be set up once
column14: and everyone can use them consistently across projects.  First of all
column15: you set up a directory on your local system containing just the things you want to add to a standard layout (maybe a replacement
column16: perhaps a new  ).  Whatever you put in this folder will be merged into newly minted projects.  You can choose to overwrite files
column17: or add new ones alongside.  Then you simply do: Each time you now issue the command  a new project is created that also incorporates your template automatically.  You can have as many templates as you want.  just type to see what\'s currently installed.  If you have a particular template that you use a lot
column18: you can set it to be the default: after which
column19: every time you do that template will be automatically applied
column20: saving you some typing.  There is also the ability to use a template that someone has shared on github maybe a scripted workflow for a particular problem domain.  To do this
column21: you first add it to your template collection: This is a template I have created to assist with text data mining and analysis.  If you now do then you will have a new project structure specifically tailored to get you started with text mining.  If you do this yourself as an example
column22: you\'ll find a README which explains how to use this particular template to help analyse a big corpus of text.  By including the github option
column23: I hope to enable the community to easily share analysis work flows among each other.  It also allows the functionality of to be extended and customised for lots of different situations without needing to have the core code updated.  If you would like to test drive this feature while this PR is under review
column24: you can get the functionality by There\'s a lot more beside what I\'ve described here.  Type to get the full feature set
column25: including special handling for templates.  I look forward to seeing comments and feedback.  "'

column10: b"b' Make () compatible with clear() and ()'"

b'b" This PR proposes an extension to the function to take account of recent additions to in a more natural way.  The existing behaviour is to clear the global environment and then run again. The PR essentially does the same but takes account of more factors:  There is a new parameter which are for specific datasets that may take a long time to load and the user doesn\'t want them cleared during a  .  These are now also honoured during  There is a new paramer so if is called
column11: then everything is cleared from both Global env and  cache regardless (the project is reset). The parameter is used to capture any additonal parameters to pass to (e.g.  ).  This was hard coded before
column12: but it\'s more generic to use the dots notation.  The documentation for has been updated.  I couldn\'t see any relevant parts of the website documentation that should be updated."'

column10: b'b" I agree that the expected behavior is that *all* data is removed and reloaded from scratch. I\'m a bit worried about removing cache items using  .  Let\'s imagine the user with all of their long loading data stored in cache. After an update they run expecting the old behavior and for whatever reason some of those variables are missing from the global environment. now wipes out their cache and they are stuck with a long rebuild time.  If we are removing items from cache with I\'d feel more comfortable if we provide a confirmation for cached items that will be removed. This way a user can prevent a disastrous mistake!"'
b'b" I see your point.   Can we break down the cases between how it might work going forward
column11: and what a user expects after updating to the latest  ?  We can help the latter through if we detect they have things in the cache.  So ..... should the new behaviour be: if I I want everything re-calculated from scratch
column12: so clear both memory and cache  if I have declared certain variables to be protected in
column13: then I want them to remain in memory  cache during a reload  Even if I have declared
column14: I want to consciously erase everything anyway
column15: so I set  I think points 2 and 3 are not contentious the user is in control of what\'s happening.  With point 1
column16: it boils down to whether most of the time users expect to have both and when doing a reload.  I did toy with the idea of creating a function which did both and leave to just clear global env but this seems even more confusing for a user to have to remember.  On balance
column17: I\'m agnostic on clearing the cache in case 1.  I can see the benefits
column18: and I can see the other side.  Let me rework the PR to just use  .  We can always add in later if required.  Are you still comfortable with case 3 having a parameter explicitly set to clear everything?"'

column10: b'b" OK
column11: this is the reworked PR for review.  I also edited the original post above for the record so it describes what\'s now implemented.  The behaviour is essentially the same as before
column12: except that is honoured and there is a new parameter to allow a complete scrub out and reload if that\'s what the user wants."'

b"b' Add  and incorporate in '"
b'b\' First of all
column11: sorry for the rather largish PR. # Background While testing PR #178 (to be able to ignore files) an issue surfaced that sometimes data was loaded from cache even though the source was ignored. This happens because the cache loading and data loading are two completely separate stages in  . Also
column12: the older issues #137 / #140 point out that converting to doesn\\\'t work properly when the actual variable name is different from the variable name suggested by the file name. Furthermore
column13: from a maintenance standpoint in its current form is rather hard to read as some of the actions are implemented within the function
column14: while other actions are dispatched to separate functions. Also
column15: some optimisation is possible by not looping over the for every file separately. # General solution To overcome the inconsistent behaviour of ignoring datasets all available data should be gathered in a single function
column16: in which also should be determined whether the cached state is valid
column17: what reader should be used if necessary
column18: etc. In the and functions should be integrated into one function that loads the data from cache if possible and otherwise uses the predetermined reader to load the data from source. The problem of readers generating different variable names from the suggested variable name can be overcome by determining the difference in which variables exist right before and after the reader is called. That way only the new variables are processed in further steps. These new variables can then be converted to if necessary. While changing the functionality of the data  it is nice to extract this functionality into separate functions to make the logic behind the function more clear. # Implementation This PR provides the following new functionality:  ## Major changes: All new function that shows a list of the files and variables that will be loaded by
column19: including meta data such as its cache state and the configured reader. It can be called before loading the project as long as it\\\'s provided the configuration. All changes were implemented using test driven development
column20: so there are more lines of tests than new code and every aspect of the function should be tested under different circumstances. (  is not exported) All new function that wraps calls to and (  is exported
column21: but is useful mostly for debugging ignore patterns and determining which reader will be used) Merged into by using the new function. This makes the loading process much more efficient. The separate "Loading cache" stage is removed
column22: and now shows whether the data was loaded from source or cache. Variables that exist in the cache only are loaded first so readers that output more than one variable can skip existing variables.  Merged converting to and auto caching into the function for efficiency  ## Minor changes Added more comments throughout these functions for clarity Moved function (introduced by the data ignore PR) to as that\\\'s a more logical location New function that currently wraps but allows a vector of variables as input. Should be expanded in a separate PR to do more checking on cache validity. Several helper functions for that more clearly show the program flow during project loading. They all have the same signature
column23: and all return even though some of the functions don\\\'t actually modify  .\''

column10: b'b"   is mostly an interactive tool that helps test ignore patterns
column11: custom readers
column12: that kind of things. Mostly a debugging tool therefore as it lists exacly what will load into memory. The function is the true workhorse that is also called by my new version of
column13: it builds the definitive list of all variables that should be loaded into memory. By building a list with both the cached and raw variables the ignore patterns are applied more consistently. Also
column14: I noticed some performance improvement in the tests since a few of the original loops are vectorised now (for example the whole list of available readers is processed just once instead of for every variable separately).  I\'m sorry it\'s such a long list of changes
column15: but by itself doesn\'t make much sense (especially when it\'s listing different things from what\'s actually loaded)
column16: while it\'s essential to the rewritten data loading phase. The other changes to could perhaps have been moved to a separate PR but the original function did so many things within a single function call that it was sometimes hard to grasp what the main components were. By moving those components to separate functions the function itself became structured more clearly
column17: while the new functions explain self-contained parts of the process."'

column10: b'b\' I\\\'m afraid I\\\'m struggling to review this PR.  One the one hand
column11: I can\\\'t visualise a problem that solves for me
column12: so I have no reference point to know if what it does is correct or not.  I am generally concerned that a lot of internal functions are changing to support it.  It\\\'s not a problem to change internal implementation per se
column13: but there needs to be strong reasons driven by user requirements (not just "it\\\'s better this way").  Another issue I have is that there a lot of inconsequential edits that are getting in the way.  There shouldn\\\'t be a need to add and delete blank .  Neither should code be re-written to do exactly the same thing (e.g. removing from message calls that result in exactly the same message being output).  It all just gets in the way of a review.  Related to the last point
column14: I can\\\'t tell whether is fundamentally changing or not.  That\\\'s a function I do care passionately about and would like to be satisfied I know what\\\'s going on inside it (beyond the fact that the tests still pass).  Is there a way you can break the PR into more manageable chunks for review?\''

column10: b'b" The changes in whitespace are (a bit) annoying
column11: I agree
column12: but is the effect of the RStudio project settings. I think the latest version of RStudio started to change sourcefiles according to those settings on saving the file because I do not remember that occuring unless code was actually copy-pasted. It\'s not that I want to start a white space war
column13: but we might want to consider a standard (the project\'s defaults are 2 spaces
column14: I prefer 4 but use the 2
column15: and I think @connectedblue uses 8). I\'m not sure how best to resolve this issue that keeps popping up. I noticed though that the changes are visible more clearly in split view than in the default unified view.  Regarding  : The only real changes are the added function (which  at a later point be adapted for better cache invalidation) and the removal of as it is no longer a separate stage in  . I very much respect the improvements of the caching mechanism you made
column16: and the heart of the cache loading was simply copied into the new version of the function. I do not mean to change the file just to have my name tagged on it :-)  could be removed without too much trouble
column17: but I think the is a large improvement of the  / . It\'s not that  /  could not exist without changing the loading process but that there were inconsistencies in the loading process with previously cached data loaded if ignored later. That was an issue that was caught during the testing of #178. The only way around that
column19: was to disable either auto caching or loading from cache at all.  With the new functionality the list of all available variables is compiled once
column21: and marked whether it is cached. That\'s all very nice
column22: but if the actual loading of the data does something different there is no point in adding this function. The other way around
column23: changing without makes no sense either. Therefore I changed simultaneously
column24: which as a bonus reduced some overhead as well. Some of the minor changes to could perhaps be moved to another PR
column25: but I\'m not sure it\'s that easy or that the separate PR will be much clearer with the moved lines. I do think the separation of into functions representing the main components is better
column26: even though it doesn\'t change user functionality. The code is much cleaner now and easier to maintain
column27: and perhaps all the if statements that remain in should move to the separate functions as well.  I do not agree with you that changes that make the code cleaner without changing user functionality should be avoided. Consider being a new developer who wants to see what does. Previously it was a long list of code with some actions dispatched to other functions while other things were happening inline. Now it is a small list of functions that is applied
column28: with rather descriptive names that show exactly what happens in which order. As said
column29: the is mostly a debugging tool that helps in cases like you experienced with the ignore patterns in reviewing #178. If you prefer to not export the functionality at all that\'s fine by me
column30: but all tests have to be rewritten to either or to point to  . Changing to is not much work at all and keeps the tests to a single unit of functionality (great!)
column31: but then we are also testing internal functions (not so great..). Changing to is much more involved and only tests user functions (great!)
column32: but then again it is more an integration test than a unit test (not so great..) where effects are tested indirectly without being sure  changes to affect  .  Again
column33: I\'m sorry it seems like a massive rewrite
column34: which is made worse by the visualisation of the diffs
column35: but I still think it\'s a consistent set of changes which isn\'t easily broken down into smaller pieces that are clearer. I would therefore prefer to keep the PR as it is unless you or @KentonWhite could point out some logical subsets of the changes that can be applied without manually rewriting everything as upstream changes were incorporated in the commits at least twice (apparently the link between the commits in a PR and the upstream master is broken when squashing commits once the PR is merged)."'

column10: b'b\' OK

I must admit I haven\\\'t delved into the new structure in the raw file I was trying to understand from the diff files only to build up a picture of the changes.  This is where it got confusing for me.  I\\\'ll go and look at the clean source files.  I\\\'m not sure either how it can be split up.  The PR was about a function

column13: when developing #160

I\\\'ll have a review of the clean source code and see if that helps shed any light.  I prefer to raise a PR in a way that states a problem and then proposes a solution.  That way
column15: we can debate whether or not it is a generic problem faced by lots of users
column17: does the proposed solution solve all aspects of the problem in a reasonable way.  At the moment
column18: you\\\'re are stating the problem as "poor maintainability of  " and proposing a solution.  I\\\'m not sold yet on this as being a problem
column19: although I agree there are brittle issues with the way multiple variables are loaded from single data files (e.g. excel
column20: db etc).  If we could just find a way of being more precise with the problem being solved
column21: it would make reviewing a little easier.\''

column10: b'b" Well I just don\'t think is the place to call because you\'re running that code before load sequence of R is finished. So by putting it in a function
column11: defined in you at least move it to the end of the load sequence for more predictable results.  How many packages are you trying to install through  ? Because if you are installing the or with all dependencies it takes a while
column12: and rstudio doesn\'t draw the window until the load sequence finishes. Only after all packages are installed and all data is loaded and munged the window elements are shown
column13: so that might take a long time without any feedback.  doesn\'t cause an install loop because it always tries to load the package first
column14: I tried removing some packages and I cannot reproduce any loops
column15: just a long load time. So perhaps you can share a minimal working example project on GitHub with your entire in it and the you use so we can investigate what\'s going on
column16: but I\'m fairly certain it isn\'t an error in  ."'

column10: b"b' This seems to show that not all dependencies are installed correctly (especially is just a shortcut to installing and loading a list of dependencies with dependencies of their own
column11: each recursively calling the load sequence again). I cannot tell you why this happens during the loading sequence of R
column12: and not once R is fully loaded. I still feel that trying to do this while R is still configuring itself is not something we should actively try to support. Especially since once the packages are installed works fine from
column13: as far as I have seen. If you are expecting you need to install all packages every time you load the project then I think you should reconsider the setup of your system.'"

column10: b"b'   **does** install packages that are not already installed.  This issue is around packages that are not installing correctly.  The current implementation is a convenience and not a proper package manager. Reproducible research is important.  has a key role in reproducible research providing a unified framework for data loading
column11: munging
column12: and reporting.  A second component is package management.  This creates a reproducible environment.  This is more complicated than running when a package is missing (which is what does).  Here are the key features of a package manager for reproducible research that are beyond the scope of  : Install from sources other than CRAN.  This includes GitHub and even private packages Handle package conflicts.  This issue is highlights that importance.  Sometimes packages depend on conflicting packages
column13: so loading one will interfere with loading others. Handle package versions.  This is the most important step for reproducible research.  Older versions of packages may have features or bugs that are no longer available or present in the current version.  Simply loading the current CRAN version does not guarantee that the analysis will be reproduced.  We had a good discussion on including a package manager in  .  On the pro side of this was that is opinionated.  Some in the community wanted to have an opinion on how package management should be handled and which package manager is preferred.  On the con side there were just too many use cases.  With the different repositories and complexities of each project
column14: picking a single package manager was too confining. In the end we agreed that works well **in tandem** with a package manager of your choice.  The precedent is other communities
column15: like Ruby which have Rails (the framework) and Bundler (the package manager) and Python
column16: which has PIP separate.  A package manager like does all of this management for you automatically.  If you have installed
column17: it checks that you have all of the packages from your environment installed to the correct versions when R starts.'"

b"b' Discussion: Force quality control'"

b'b\' #### Report an Issue / Request a Feature  I\\\'m submitting a (Check one with "x") :  [ ] bug report  [x] feature request  ***  ##### Issue Severity Classification (Check one with "x") :  [ ] 1 Severe [x] 2 Moderate [ ] 3 Low  ##### Expected Behavior  Currently everyone with write access to the repository can create commits directly on the master branch. I think we should set the GitHub settings such that commits can only be made through a pull request by making a protected branch.  Also
column11: I think we should enforce at least one approving review before a pull request can be merged. This way no changes can be made to the code without a second person looking into those changes.  It\\\'s not that I distrust anyone but a mistake is easily made and this way at least one other person has looked at the mistake and not realised the implications if it was merged after all. So it\\\'s more a distrust towards my own code ;-) \''

column10: b'b" Yep
column11: I agree 100%. This is very traditional of most high-traffic collaborative repositories. Like you said
column12: it\'s not about distrust
column13: but it does drive more eyes on a merge into the master code resulting not only in mistakes being identified but even helps drive standardization of the documentation & code base."'

column10: b'b\' Thanks @Hugovdberg for looking into this.  The documentation says that the default "auto" uses "radix" for short numeric vectors
column11: integer vectors
column12: logical vectors and factors. Otherwise it uses "shell".  The biggest difference between "shell" and "radix" is that "radix" uses the [local comparison]url  while "shell" uses a hard-coded comparison.  This would give "shell" a slight performance boost for characters and why it was chosen.  it also explains why it failed in this example.  The Chinese character ordering is not defined in "shell" but radix uses the ordering for the location where it is defined.  I don\\\'t see any any obvious problem moving to "radix".  In general
column13: Project Template recommends starting each file with a number
column14: so moving to radix shouldn\\\'t affect most projects.\''
